results.title: Journeys in space and time
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode Carl Sagan explores the relationship of space and time. He begins by showing how the shape of the constellations would change over millions of years, as the stars move and evolve, and then launches into a discussion on the speed of light and Einstein’s theory of relativity, concluding with the tantalising possibilities of time travel and parallel universes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International

results.title: One voice in the cosmic fugue
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
Carl Sagan explores the nature of life on earth from its earliest beginnings to the present. The use of computer animation vividly explains evolution and the structure of the cell and DNA, and the real-life example of the Japanese Heike crab whose form has gradually changed through human intervention, demonstrates the process of artificial selection. Although human life is but one branch of the evolutionary tree we are now influencing all other branches. Sagan concludes by speculating on different paths that evolution may take on other worlds with quite different environments.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel

results.title: The Emperor and the nightingale
results.creator_credit: Mark Sottnick, Joel Tuber, Rabbit Ears Productions and Windham Hill
results.brief_description: Glenn Close narrates Hans Christian Andersen’s story of the Chinese emperor who discovers that the song of a free nightingale, is more beautiful and more valuable by far, than the finest and cleverest, bejewelled mechanical singing bird. The exquisite illustrations are by Robert Van Nutt and the evocative music is by Mark Isham.

results.title: The Shores of the cosmic ocean
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, Rob McCain, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
From the shores of the great ocean of space, Carl Sagan begins his contemplation of the universe. His aim is to find out how we achieved our understanding of the cosmos, how the cosmos shaped us and what is its future. A tour of the universe is followed by a detailed look at the library of Alexandria, where the intellectual adventure which led us into space began. The program concludes with Sagan’s “cosmic calendar” to make comprehensible the vast expanse of time from the Big Bang to the present.

results.title: The Harmony of the worlds
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
All over the world, our ancestors in every culture taught themselves astronomy. Their lives quite literally depended on it. But the journey from the earliest astronomers to the modern day detoured into the pseudo-science of astrology. The last scientific astrologer, was also the first modern astronomer: Johannes Kepler, and this program looks at Kepler’s struggle to find a harmony in the heavens, in the process making the critical step which was to move us into the scientific age.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International

results.title: The Origin of life
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
Adapted from Cosmos the television series by Carl Sagan, this film examines the role of the nucleus in cell activity; describes the process by which an identical genetic message can be made for each cell in a living organism; shows the commonality of all living things on earth and recreates an experimental attempt to duplicate the formation of the first complex organic molecules on earth. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer and Films Incorporated

results.title: The Electric grandmother
results.creator_credit: Noel Black, Doro Bachrach and Highgate Pictures
results.brief_description: An adaptation of the Ray Bradbury story “I Sing the Body Electric”. A young family who lose their mother through death are subsequently delivered an electric ‘grandmother’ who seeks to provide for all their needs, both emotional and physical. This film provides an insight inside into child versus adult perceptions of growth, ageing, human relationships and man’s motivation for creating machines

results.title: The Backbone of night
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode, Carl Sagan describes man’s long exploration of the cosmos as a voyage of self-discovery. His thesis that “we make our world significant by the courage of our questions and the depth of our answers” is illustrated by man’s quest to explain the cosmos through periods of intellectual growth and periods of repression. From our primitive ancestors’ ideas of the heavens, through Greek science and philosophy, to the Renaissance, the age of reason and the modern day, Sagan attempts to convey a sense of wonder and excitement about the exploration of the natural universe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International

results.title: Encyclopaedia galactica
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode Carl Sagan tackles the question of the possibilities of life on other planets. In spite of the lack of compelling credible evidence that alien visitors have visited our planet, Sagan demonstrates the probability of life existing elsewhere in the universe, and some of the possible forms this life might take. He also discusses the possibility of interstellar communication and how this might be interpreted, using the example of the deciphering of Egyptian hieroglyphics by Jean Francois Champollion, posing the notion that the laws of science are a common language, a kind of Rosetta Stone.

results.title: Travellers' tales
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, Intel and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode Carl Sagan follows man’s passion to explore, from the Dutch sailors of the seventeenth century to the Voyager project and its rendezvous with Jupiter and its moons in 1979. He compares the change in vision that came with Christian Huygens’ study of light and astronomy in the seventeenth century and the impact of the detailed pictures sent back by the Voyager spacecraft on the scientists of today. The video includes a fairly detailed look at Jupiter and its moons and at life in seventeenth century Holland.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, Intel and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
